Dear FRANCISCO GONZALEZ:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact Jessica VandenHeuvel, the area manager at (616) 204-
6992.

Allegation Youth A shared that she went on an outing with a boy from school,
and he brought along a friend. Youth A admitted that she was
offered marijuana which she smoked, and that the boy's friend
drove them downtown to an apartment. Youth A said that she was
not feeling well, and that the boy from school insisted that they
have sex. He then told her that they were going to have sex
whether she wanted to or not, and he did. Youth A said that once
he was done having sex with her, he proceeded to call her names
and told her that he was going to take her home. On the drive
home, she said that she grabbed his neck but stopped as the two
boys got upset and threatened to beat her if she continued. Youth
A shared that the boy who sexually assaulted her is from school
and his name is Youth B. The other boy who was driving the car
she believes to be named Youth C.
Investigation Assistant Supervisor was interviewed face to face at the
facility on 1/9/2024. She reported knowing very little of the
allegations. She was able to identify there is a safety plan in place
and a copy will be provided.
Complainant/Therapist was interviewed via phone on
1/9/2024. She reported having no further information about the
allegations but did provide an update on information she has
learned since the allegations took place. A safety plan has been
developed and the school wants to also develop a safety plan
since Youth B goes to the same high school and Youth A and
Youth B have a class together. She also reported the allegations
took place on 12/29/2023 when Youth A went on an approved
outing. Youth A did not tell Complainant/Therapist until 1/5/2024 at
which time Complainant/Therapist called MDHHS. She reported
Youth A had earned the right to an outing and staff believed Youth
A understood how to be safe in the community. Youth A had
informed staff she was going to a nearby park with Youth B to
hang out. Youth A informed complainant/Therapist the plan
changed once Youth B offered marijuana to Youth A. Youth A
reported a friend of Youth B drove them to an apartment in Grand
2

Rapids where Youth B sexually abused Youth A. Youth A also
reported not feeling well being under the influence of the
marijuana. Complainant/Therapist reported the outing was

the outing for no more than four to five hours and have to share
the details of what they are planning on doing.
Complainant/Therapist also reported the primary focus of the
program is the development of independent living skills for the
youth.
Administrator 1 was interviewed via phone on 1/9/2024. She
reported knowing about the allegations and she approved the
outing for Youth A. The process of a youth obtaining an outing is
they must have reached a specific level, apply to access an
outing, and submit a request form that Administrator 1 reviews.
Case Manager was interviewed via phone on 1/12/2024. She
reported Youth A has not spoken to her about the allegations, but
Case Manager acknowledged knowing about the allegations. She
reported being the case manager for Youth A for the past four
weeks.
Administrator 1, Administrator 2, Administrator 3, Supervisor,

other policies are being updated because there have been
changes.
Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
1/26/2024. She reported being approached by Youth A and Youth
A telling Staff 1, Youth A was abused by someone. Youth A
informed Staff 1 that Youth A told Youth D who suggested Youth
A tell staff. Youth A also informed Staff 1, Youth A thought
hanging out with Youth B was a good idea to begin with and they
were supposed to meet at a local park. Youth A reported to Staff
1, Youth B picked Youth A up in a car and gave Youth A
something to smoke, which Youth A smoked. Staff 1 reported
calling the police immediately, but she was unable to give the
address of the apartment because Youth A didn’t have that
information.
Staff 2 was interviewed face to face at the facility on
1/26/2024. Staff 2 reported being present when Youth A left on the
outing with Youth B. She verified Youth A had authorization for the
outing by checking the outing documents and had Youth A
register in the outing book before leaving. Staff 2 asked Youth A

Independent Outings without a date. This document indicates
youth can earn outing privileges by completing life skills
curriculum. Once youth complete their third life skills curriculum,
they can complete a formal application for independent outings.
The decision to grant the request involves the treatment team and
if granted, the youth will meet with the treatment team and discuss
the guidelines for the outing. The request for an outing must take
place two days prior to the outing and the youth must provide the
following information: day/time, location, with who, what they plan
to do, and the plan for transportation. Outing are to occur on
weekends. Approval of the request is made by the Program
Supervisor or assistant supervisor. Youth are not allowed to go to
another person’s house or travel outside of the county without
prior approval. If the youth doesn’t have a cell phone the facility
will provide a cell phone for the youth’s use during the outing. If
5

called by staff during the outing and the youth fails to respond, the
youth may lose the outing privilege in the future. If staff suspect
the youth has used a substance during the outing, they are
subject to a drug test. During the weekends, outing can take place
no earlier than 8 am and the return time is no later than 9 pm. If a
youth doesn’t return within an hour of their scheduled return time,
they will be considered AWOL. Youth on level 1 must use staff to
transport and if on level 2 they are to use public transportation.
Youth are not to ride in the car of an individual unless that
individual is a foster parent, cleared volunteer or another
authorized individual.

Interview Summary for Youth A dated 1/10/2024. This
6

document is the forensic interview of Youth A and within this

Analysis Based upon interviews and written documentation there is
evidence that supports staff did not received the required 2-day
prior request for the outing on 12/29/23. Although there is a
request for an outing by Youth A for 12/29/23 there is no date
when this request was made. The request must include a plan for
transportation, but this is not an area on the request form that
youth can completed. Each of the request forms used by Youth A
did not have the decision to approve or deny marked on the form
and there was no supervisor signature and date on any of the
request forms. These is no documentation that Youth A met with
the treatment team to discuss outings as required in the policy on
outings. The documents of Youth A completing all the
requirements for outing are not completed and several have the
start date but no completion date. The policy for independent
outing is not completed and ends after PIE 5. PIE 6 and PIE 7 are
documented as being under development. There is evidence
Youth A did not follow the outing policy when she took
transportation with Youth B and Youth C.
Given the policy and program statement that this program is
designed to provide independent living skills for youth and youth
are allowed to go on outing without direct staff supervision, there
is no violation for a lack of supervision by staff.
Technical Assistance:
The facility needs to review and update the outing policies and
procedures to what they are practicing and train staff on following the
protocol to determine if an unsupervised outing is appropriate.
It was recommended and discussed the facility ensure all forms are
completed since several did not have the signatures and dates since
there was a signature line and date line on the form. The facility
agreed that these items needed to be completed.
Conclusion Violation Established
